chunks.title: Short title, extent, commencement and application
chunks.summary: This Act is called the Companies Act, 2013. It applies to companies incorporated under this act or any other, insurance companies except where their provisions conflict with specific acts, banking companies excluding conflicts with a particular act, electricity-related companies excluding conflicts with another act, and certain other bodies as specified by the Central Government.

chunks.title: abridged prospectus
chunks.text: ( 1 ) “abridged prospectus” means a memorandum containing such salient features of a prospectus as may be specified by the Securities and Exchange Board by making regulations in this behalf;
chunks.summary: An "abridged prospectus" is defined as a document that includes only essential information from a full prospectus, as determined by the Securities and Exchange Board through regulations.

chunks.title: Formation of company
chunks.summary: One Person Company (OPC) is a unique type of private company where only one individual can hold the shares. To form an OPC, seven or more persons must agree, and it requires subscription to a memorandum of association for registration in accordance with this Act. Key points include shareholder consent, written notification upon death or incapacity of another person, ability to change the name without withdrawing prior consent, and right to alter MOA/AAO as needed.

chunks.summary: A public company must form as a shareholding limited company, while a private company should also be formed as a shareholding limited company. If the number of members falls below seven for a public company or two for a private company after more than six months of operation and continued business, former members are liable to pay off debts contracted during that period.

chunks.summary: A minimum paid-up share capital applies to public companies. Subsidiary companies of non-private companies are considered public companies under this act, provided they remain private in their articles.

chunks.title: Formation of company - Subsection 1
chunks.text:
(1) A may be formed for any lawful purpose by—

( a ) seven or more persons, where the company to be formed is to be a ; ( b ) two or more persons, where the company to be formed is to be a ; or ( c ) , where the company to be formed is to be that is to say, a private company, by subscribing their names or his name to a and complying with the requirements of this Act in respect of registration:

that the memorandum of One Person Company shall indicate the name of the other person, with his prior written consent in the , who shall, in the event of the subscriber’s death or his incapacity to contract become the of the company and the written consent of such person shall also be filed the at the time of incorporation of the One Person Company along with its memorandum and articles:

Provided further that such other person may withdraw his consent in such manner as may be :

Provided also that the member of One Person Company may at any time change the name of such other person by giving notice in such manner as may be :

Provided also that it shall be the duty of the member of One Person Company to intimate the company the change, if any, in the name of the other person nominated by him by indicating in the memorandum or otherwise within such time and in such manner , and the company shall intimate the Registrar any such change within such time and in such manner as may be :

Provided also that any such change in the name of the person shall not be deemed to be an of the memorandum.
chunks.summary: A one-person company can be formed by seven or more persons, two or more persons, or a private company. The memorandum must indicate the other person's consent and specify their role upon death or incapacity. Members may change the name of the nominated person within specified timeframes and inform the registrar about any changes in the same manner.

chunks.title: Memorandum
chunks.summary: The text discusses provisions for companies registered under the Companies Act, including details about their names and objects. It specifies that if a company is a Specified IFSC, its name must include 'International Financial Service Company' or 'IFSC'. The text also outlines the requirements for incorporation of these types of companies. For compliance purposes, this seems to be related to preliminary and applicability.

chunks.title: Memorandum - Subsection 1 Clause 1
chunks.text: (1) The of a shall state—
chunks.summary: The document specifies that the of a shall state—

chunks.text: (a) the name of the company with the last word in the case of a public limited company, or the last words in the case of a private limited company: Provided that nothing in this clause shall apply to a company registered under section 8; a Specified IFSC public company shall have the suffix “International Financial Service Company” or “IFSC” as part of its name. that a Specified IFSC private company shall have the suffix “International Financial Service Company” or “IFSC” as part of its name
chunks.summary: The text specifies that public limited companies should end with "Limited" and private companies with "Private Limited," unless they are registered under section 8, in which case their names must include the suffix "International Financial Service Company" or "IFSC."

chunks.title: Memorandum - Subsection 1 Clause c
chunks.text: (c) the objects for which the company is proposed to be incorporated and any matter considered necessary in furtherance thereof; a Specified IFSC shall state its objects to do financial services activities, as permitted under the Special Economic Zones Act, 2005 (28 of 2005) read with the Special Economic Zones Rules, 2006 and any matter considered necessary in furtherance thereof, in accordance with license to operate, from International Financial Services Centre located in an approved multi services Special Economic Zone, granted by the Reserve Bank of India or the Securities and Exchange Board of India or the Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority of India. a Specified IFSC private company shall state its objects to do financial services activities, as permitted under the Special Economic Zones Act, 2005 read with the Special Economic Zones Rules, 2006 and any matter considered necessary in furtherance thereof, in accordance with license to operate, from International Financial Services Centre located in an approved multi services Special Economic Zone, granted by the Reserve Bank of India or the Securities and Exchange Board of India or the Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority of India.
chunks.summary: A Specified IFSC must specify its objects for incorporation to engage in financial services activities as permitted under the Special Economic Zones Act, 2005, read with the Special Economic Zones Rules, 2006. It must obtain a license from the Reserve Bank of India or Securities and Exchange Board of India or Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority of India operating within an approved multi-service Special Economic Zone.

chunks.title: Memorandum - Subsection 1 Clause i
chunks.text: (i) Upon receipt of an application under sub-section (4), the Registrar may, on the basis of information and documents furnished along with the application, reserve the name for a period of sixty day from the date of the application. Upon receipt of an application under sub-section (4), the Registrar may, on the basis of information and furnished along with the application, the name for a period of twenty days from the date of approval or such other period as may be prescribed: Provided that in case of an application for reservation of name or for change of its name by an existing company, the Registrar may reserve the name for a period of sixty days from the date of approval. ( ii ) Where after reservation of name under clause ( i ), it is found that name was applied by furnishing wrong or incorrect information, then,—
chunks.summary: Upon receipt of an application under sub-section (4), the Registrar may reserve a company's name for sixty days from the date of approval. For applications involving changes to existing companies, the period is twenty days. If there are errors in applying for or changing a name, the Registrar can extend this period up to sixty days after approval.

chunks.title: Memorandum - Subsection 1
chunks.text:
(1) The of a shall state—

( a )  the name of the company with the last word in the case of a public limited company, or the last words in the case of a private limited company:

Provided that nothing in this clause shall apply to a company registered under section 8;

a Specified IFSC public company shall have the suffix “International Financial Service Company” or “IFSC” as part of its name.

that a Specified IFSC private company shall have the suffix “International Financial Service Company” or “IFSC” as part of its name

( b ) the State in which the registered office of the company is to be situated;

( c ) the objects for which the company is proposed to be incorporated and any matter considered necessary in furtherance thereof;

a Specified IFSC shall state its objects to do financial services activities, as permitted under the Special Economic Zones Act, 2005 (28 of 2005) read with the Special Economic Zones Rules, 2006 and any matter considered necessary in furtherance thereof, in accordance with license to operate, from International Financial Services Centre located in an approved multi services Special Economic Zone, granted by the Reserve Bank of India or the Securities and Exchange Board of India or the Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority of India.

a Specified IFSC private company shall state its objects to do financial services activities, as permitted under the Special Economic Zones Act, 2005 read with the Special Economic Zones Rules, 2006 and any matter considered necessary in furtherance thereof, in accordance with license to operate, from International Financial Services Centre located in an approved multi services Special Economic Zone, granted by the Reserve Bank of India or the Securities and Exchange Board of India or the Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority of India.

( d ) the liability of of the company, whether limited or unlimited, and also state,—

( i ) in the case of a , that liability of its members is limited to the amount unpaid, if any, on the held by them; and

( ii ) in the case of a , the amount up to which each member undertakes to contribute—

( A ) to the assets of the company in the event of its being wound-up while he is a member or within one year after he ceases to be a member, for payment of the debts and liabilities of the company or of such debts and liabilities as may have been contracted before he ceases to be a member, as the case may be; and

( B ) to the costs, charges and expenses of winding-up and for adjustment of the rights of the contributories among themselves;

( e ) in the case of a company having a share capital,—

( i ) the amount of share capital with which the company is to be registered and the division thereof into shares of a fixed amount and the number of shares which the subscribers to the memorandum agree to subscribe which shall not be less than one share; and

( ii ) the number of shares each subscriber to the memorandum intends to take, indicated opposite his name;

( f ) in the case of , the name of the person who in the event of death of the subscriber shall become the member of the company.
chunks.summary: The company's name must include its registered office state. A Specified IFSC public/private company should specify financial services activities permitted under relevant laws in an approved Special Economic Zone. The liability of members is limited to unpaid amounts or contributions as specified, and the share capital details are required for companies with a share structure.

- Be identical with or closely resemble existing companies registered under this Act.
- Cause offenses under current laws.

chunks.text:

( a ) any word or expression which is likely to give the impression that the company is in any way connected with, or having the patronage of, the Central Government, any State Government, or any local authority, corporation or body constituted by the Central Government or any State Government under any law for the time being in force; or

( b ) such word or expression, as may be

unless the previous approval of the Central Government has been obtained for the use of any such word or expression.

chunks.title: Memorandum - Subsection 4
chunks.text:
(4) A person may make an application, in such and accompanied by , to the for the reservation of a name set out in the application as—

( a ) the name of the proposed company; or

( b ) the name to which the company proposes to change its name.
chunks.summary: A person can apply to reserve a name, either that of the proposed company or one it intends to change.

chunks.title: Memorandum - Subsection 5
chunks.text:
(5) ( i ) Upon receipt of an application under sub-section (4), the Registrar may, on the basis of information and documents furnished along with the application, reserve the name for a period of sixty day from the date of the application.

Upon receipt of an application under sub-section (4), the Registrar may, on the basis of information and furnished along with the application, the name for a period of twenty days from the date of approval or such other period as may be prescribed:

Provided that in case of an application for reservation of name or for change of its name by an existing company, the Registrar may reserve the name for a period of sixty days from the date of approval.

( ii ) Where after reservation of name under clause ( i ), it is found that name was applied by furnishing wrong or incorrect information, then,—

( a ) if the company has not been incorporated, the reserved name shall be cancelled and the person making application under sub-section (4) shall be liable to a penalty which may extend to one lakh rupees;

( b ) if the company has been incorporated, the Registrar may, after giving the company an opportunity of being heard—

( i ) either direct the company to change its name within a period of three months, after passing an ordinary resolution;

( ii ) take action for striking off the name of the company from the ; or

( iii ) make a petition for winding up of the company.
chunks.summary: Upon receipt of an application under sub-section (4), the Registrar may reserve a name for 60 days based on provided information. For applications involving companies, if the reserved name is later found incorrect, the Registrar can either require immediate changes or take further actions as prescribed. If the company has been incorporated, it must change its name within three months after approval or face penalties.

chunks.title: Articles
chunks.summary: The document specifies that articles of association must include provisions for management regulations and may contain additional matters deemed necessary. Articles can be entrenchable but require specific conditions or procedures met by a resolution. Entrenched provisions apply only during company formation, amendments agreed to by all members, or special resolutions.

chunks.title: Articles - Subsection 1 Clause 1
chunks.text: (1) The of a shall contain the regulations for management of the company. (2) The articles shall also contain such matters, as may be : Provided that nothing prescribed in this sub-section shall be deemed to prevent a company from including such additional matters in its articles as may be considered necessary for its management. (3) The articles may contain provisions for entrenchment to the effect that specified provisions of the articles may be only if conditions or procedures as that are more restrictive than those applicable in the case of a special resolution, are met or complied with. (4) The provisions for entrenchment referred to in sub-section (3) shall only be made either on formation of a company, or by an amendment in the articles agreed to by all the of the company in the case of a and by a special resolution in the case of a . (5) Where the articles contain provisions for entrenchment, whether made on formation or by amendment, the company shall give notice to the Registrar of such provisions in such as may be . (6) The articles of a company shall be in respective forms specified in Tables G, I and J in as may be applicable to such company. (7) A company may adopt all or any of the regulations contained in the model articles applicable to such company. (8) In case of any company, which is registered after the commencement of this Act, in so far as the registered articles of such company do not exclude or modify the regulations contained in the model articles applicable to such company, those regulations shall, so far as applicable, be the regulations of that company in the same manner and to the extent as if they were contained in the duly registered articles of the company. (9) Nothing in this section shall apply to the articles of a company registered under any unless amended under this Act. Articles means the articles of association of a company as originally framed or as altered from time to time or applied in pursuance of any previous company law or of this Act Company means a company incorporated under this Act or under any previous company law  of The Companies (Incorporation) Rules, 2014.  alter includes the making of additions, omissions and substitutions.
chunks.summary: The articles shall contain regulations for management, but additional matters may be included as necessary provided they do not violate this sub-section's restrictions on entrenchment conditions or procedures. The provisions for entrenchment must be made either at formation or by amendment with specific conditions met in a company governed by the Act.

chunks.title: Act to over-ride memorandum, articles, etc.
chunks.text:
Save as otherwise expressly provided in this Act— ( a ) the provisions of this Act shall have effect notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in the or of a , or in any agreement executed by it, or in any resolution passed by the company in general meeting or by its , whether the same be registered, executed or passed, as the case may be, before or after the commencement of this Act; and ( b ) any provision contained in the memorandum, articles, agreement or resolution shall, to the extent to which it is repugnant to the provisions of this Act, become or be void, as the case may be. 

Save as otherwise expressly provided in this Act—

( a ) the provisions of this Act shall have effect notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in the or of a , or in any agreement executed by it, or in any resolution passed by the company in general meeting or by its , whether the same be registered, executed or passed, as the case may be, before or after the commencement of this Act; and

( b ) any provision contained in the memorandum, articles, agreement or resolution shall, to the extent to which it is repugnant to the provisions of this Act, become or be void, as the case may be.

Articles means the articles of association of a  Company as originally framed or as altered from time to time or applied in pursuance of any previous company law or of this Act

Company means a company incorporated under this Act or under any previous company law

Board of Directors , in relation to a company, means the collective body of the directors of the company
chunks.summary: The text states that provisions of this Act take precedence over conflicting laws and agreements unless expressly provided otherwise. It also clarifies what constitutes "articles" and defines "company" as those incorporated under this or previous company law, including their board of directors.

(3) On and from the date mentioned in the certificate of incorporation issued under sub-section (2), the Registrar shall allot to the company a corporate identity number, which shall be a distinct identity for the company and which shall also be included in the certificate. chunks.title: Formation of companies with charitable objects, etc - Subsection 1 Clause c
chunks.text: (c) of that sub-section, it may, by licence, allow the company to be registered under this section subject to such conditions as the Central Government deems fit and to change its name by omitting the word “Limited”, or as the case may be, the words “Private Limited” from its name and thereupon the Registrar shall, on application, register such company under this section and all the provisions of this section shall apply to that company. (6) The may, by order, revoke the licence granted to a company registered under this section if the company contravenes any of the requirements of this section or any of the conditions subject to which a licence is issued or the affairs of the company are conducted fraudulently or in a manner violative of the objects of the company or prejudicial to public interest, and without prejudice to any other action against the company under this Act, direct the company to convert its status and change its name to add the word “Limited” or the words “Private Limited”, as the case may be, to its name and thereupon the Registrar shall, without prejudice to any action that may be taken under sub-section (7), on application, register the company accordingly: Provided that no such order shall be made unless the company is given a reasonable opportunity of being heard: Provided further that a copy of every such order shall be given to the Registrar. (7) Where a licence is revoked under sub-section (6), the Central Government may, by order, if it is satisfied that it is essential in the public interest, direct that the company be wound up under this Act or amalgamated with another company registered under this section: Provided that no such order shall be made unless the company is given a reasonable opportunity of being heard. (8) Where a licence is revoked under sub-section (6) and where the Central Government is satisfied that it is essential in the public interest that the company registered under this section should be amalgamated with another company registered under this section and having similar objects, then, notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in this Act, the Central Government may, by order, provide for such amalgamation to form a single company with such constitution, properties, powers, rights, interest, authorities and privileges and with such liabilities, duties and obligations as may be specified in the order. (9) If on the winding up or dissolution of a company registered under this section, there remains, after the satisfaction of its debts and liabilities, any asset, they may be transferred to another company registered under this section and having similar objects, subject to such conditions as the may impose, or may be sold and proceeds thereof credited to t he Rehabilitation and Insolvency Fund formed under section 269. (10) A company registered under this section shall amalgamate only with another company registered under this section and having similar objects. (11) If a company makes any default in complying with any of the requirements laid down in this section, the company shall, without prejudice to any other action under the provisions of this section, be punishable with fine which shall not be less than ten lakh rupees but which may extend to one crore rupees and the and every of the company who is in default shall be punishable with fine which shall not be less than twenty-five thousand rupees but which may extend to twenty-five lakh rupees, or with both : Provided that when it is proved that the affairs of the company were conducted fraudulently, every officer in default shall be liable for action under section 447. a) Powers are delegated to Registrar of Companies vide notification S.O 1353(E). b)The Central registration center shall exercise functional jurisdiction of processing and disposal of all e-forms and related matters pertaining to registration of companies, vide notification S.O.1211(E) dated 23 March, 2016.
chunks.summary: The text allows companies to be registered under this section subject to conditions, change names by omitting "Limited" or "Private Limited," and requires the Registrar's registration upon application. Licences can be revoked for non-compliance with requirements, fraud, or public interest concerns. In such cases, the company must convert its status and name accordingly. If a licence is revoked, the Central Government may direct winding up or amalgamation under this Act if essential in public interest, provided the company has been given a reasonable opportunity to be heard.

chunks.title: Formation of companies with charitable objects, etc - Subsection 4 Clause c
chunks.text: (c) of that sub-section, it may, by licence, allow the company to be registered under this section subject to such conditions as the Central Government deems fit and to change its name by omitting the word “Limited”, or as the case may be, the words “Private Limited” from its name and thereupon the Registrar shall, on application, register such company under this section and all the provisions of this section shall apply to that company. (6) The may, by order, revoke the licence granted to a company registered under this section if the company contravenes any of the requirements of this section or any of the conditions subject to which a licence is issued or the affairs of the company are conducted fraudulently or in a manner violative of the objects of the company or prejudicial to public interest, and without prejudice to any other action against the company under this Act, direct the company to convert its status and change its name to add the word “Limited” or the words “Private Limited”, as the case may be, to its name and thereupon the Registrar shall, without prejudice to any action that may be taken under sub-section (7), on application, register the company accordingly: Provided that no such order shall be made unless the company is given a reasonable opportunity of being heard: Provided further that a copy of every such order shall be given to the Registrar. (7) Where a licence is revoked under sub-section (6), the Central Government may, by order, if it is satisfied that it is essential in the public interest, direct that the company be wound up under this Act or amalgamated with another company registered under this section: Provided that no such order shall be made unless the company is given a reasonable opportunity of being heard. (8) Where a licence is revoked under sub-section (6) and where the Central Government is satisfied that it is essential in the public interest that the company registered under this section should be amalgamated with another company registered under this section and having similar objects, then, notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in this Act, the Central Government may, by order, provide for such amalgamation to form a single company with such constitution, properties, powers, rights, interest, authorities and privileges and with such liabilities, duties and obligations as may be specified in the order. (9) If on the winding up or dissolution of a company registered under this section, there remains, after the satisfaction of its debts and liabilities, any asset, they may be transferred to another company registered under this section and having similar objects, subject to such conditions as the may impose, or may be sold and proceeds thereof credited to t he Rehabilitation and Insolvency Fund formed under section 269. (10) A company registered under this section shall amalgamate only with another company registered under this section and having similar objects. (11) If a company makes any default in complying with any of the requirements laid down in this section, the company shall, without prejudice to any other action under the provisions of this section, be punishable with fine which shall not be less than ten lakh rupees but which may extend to one crore rupees and the and every of the company who is in default shall be punishable with fine which shall not be less than twenty-five thousand rupees but which may extend to twenty-five lakh rupees, or with both : Provided that when it is proved that the affairs of the company were conducted fraudulently, every officer in default shall be liable for action under section 447. a) Powers are delegated to Registrar of Companies vide notification S.O 1353(E). b)The Central registration center shall exercise functional jurisdiction of processing and disposal of all e-forms and related matters pertaining to registration of companies, vide notification S.O.1211(E) dated 23 March, 2016.
chunks.summary: The text allows companies to be registered under the section subject to specified conditions, change their name by omitting "Limited" or "Private Limited," and register accordingly upon application. Licences can be revoked for non-compliance with requirements, fraud, or public interest concerns. In such cases, the company must convert its status and name, and the Central Government may direct a winding-up or amalgamation under certain conditions.

chunks.title: Effect of registration
chunks.text:
From the date of incorporation mentioned in the certificate of incorporation, such subscribers to the and all other persons, as may, from time to time, become of the company, shall be a by the name contained in the memorandum, capable of exercising all the functions of an incorporated company under this Act and having perpetual succession power to acquire, hold and dispose of property, both movable and immovable, tangible and intangible, to contract and to sue and be sued, by the said name. 

( i ) the subscriber to the memorandum of the company who shall be deemed to have agreed to become member of the company, and on its registration, shall be entered as member in its register of members;

( ii ) every other person who agrees in writing to become a member of the company and whose name is entered in the register of members of the company;

( iii ) every person holding shares of the company and whose name is entered as a beneficial owner in the records of a depository

Body Corporate includes a company incorporated outside India, but does not include— (i) a co-operative society registered under any law relating to co-operative societies; and (ii) any other body corporate (not being a company as defined in this Act), which the Central Government may, by notification, specify in this behalf

(i) a co-operative society registered under any law relating to co-operative societies; and

chunks.summary: The memorandum and articles define the company's members as those who agree to be part of it through the memorandum or register, hold shares in a depository, or become beneficial owners. The Central Government can specify certain bodies corporate outside India that are not companies under this Act.

chunks.title: Effect of memorandum and articles
chunks.summary: The memorandum and articles (MOA/AAO) bind a company to the same extent as if they were signed by both parties. All monies payable under MOA/AAO are debts due from members to the company. A new company must file a declaration within a specified period and verify its payment of shares before commencing business or borrowing powers.

chunks.title: Effect of memorandum and articles - Subsection 1 Clause 1
chunks.text: (1) Subject to the provisions of this Act, the and shall, when registered, bind the and the thereof to the same extent as if they respectively had been signed by the company and by each member, and contained covenants on its and his part to observe all the provisions of the memorandum and of the articles. (2) All monies payable by any member to the company under the memorandum or articles shall be a debt due from him to the company. (1) A company incorporated after the commencement of the Companies (Amendment) Act, 2019 and having a share capital shall not commence any business or exercise any borrowing powers unless—
chunks.summary: A company registered under this Act binds its members to the memorandum and articles as if they had signed them personally. Payments by members to the company are debts due from them, and no business can be started without prior approval. Companies incorporated after a specific date cannot commence operations or borrow funds unless authorized.

chunks.summary: A director files a declaration within the incorporation period, verifying it in prescribed manner. Every shareholder must have paid for subscribed shares on that date.

(3) Where no declaration has been filed with the Registrar under clause
chunks.summary: The company must file a verification of its registered office as required by section 12(2). Failure to comply incurs penalties: fifty thousand rupees for the company and one thousand rupees per day, capped at one lakh rupees.

chunks.title: Effect of memorandum and articles - Subsection 1
chunks.text:
(1) A company incorporated after the commencement of the Companies (Amendment) Act, 2019 and having a share capital shall not commence any business or exercise any borrowing powers unless—

(a) a declaration is filed by a director within a period of of the date of incorporation of the company in such form and verified in such manner as may be prescribed, with the Registrar that every subscriber to the memorandum has paid the value of the shares agreed to be taken by him on the date of making of such declaration; and

(b) the company has filed with the Registrar a verification of its registered office as provided in sub-section (2) of section 12.
chunks.summary: A company incorporated after the Companies (Amendment) Act, 2019 and having share capital must file a declaration by a director within the specified period with the Registrar. The declaration requires payment from subscribers for shares agreed upon on the date of filing. Additionally, the company must provide verification of its registered office as per section 12(2).

chunks.title: Effect of memorandum and articles - Subsection 2
chunks.text: (2) If any default is made in complying with the requirements of this section, the company shall be liable to a penalty of fifty thousand rupees and every officer who is in default shall be liable to a penalty of one thousand rupees for each day during which such default continues but not exceeding an amount of one lakh rupees.
chunks.summary: If any requirement of this section is not met, the company will face a fifty-thousand rupee fine. Each officer found in violation will be fined up to one thousand rupees per day for non-compliance but not exceeding one lakh rupees total.

chunks.title: Effect of memorandum and articles - Subsection 3
chunks.text: (3) Where no declaration has been filed with the Registrar under clause (a) of sub-section (1) within a period of one hundred and eighty days of the date of incorporation of the company and the Registrar has reasonable cause to believe that the company is not carrying on any business or operations, he may, without prejudice to the provisions of sub-section (2), initiate action for the removal of the name of the company from the register of companies under Chapter XVIII
chunks.summary: Where no declaration has been filed within one hundred and eighty days after incorporation, and the Registrar believes the company is not operating, they may remove its name from the register without violating sub-section (2).

chunks.title: Effect of memorandum and articles - Subsection 1

(b) the company has filed with the Registrar a verification of its registered office as provided in sub-­section (2) of section 12.
chunks.summary: A company incorporated after the Companies (Amendment) Ordinance, 2018 and having share capital must file a declaration within one hundred and eighty days of incorporation with the Registrar. The declaration must be verified by every subscriber paying the agreed value on the date of filing. Additionally, the company must provide a verification of its registered office as per section 12(2).

chunks.summary: If any requirement of this section is not met, the company will face a fifty-thousand rupee fine. Each officer found in violation will be fined up to one thousand rupees per day for non-compliance but not exceeding one lakh rupees total.

chunks.title: Commencement of business, etc. -Omitted
chunks.text:
(1) A having a share capital shall not commence any business or exercise any borrowing powers unless— ( a ) a declaration is filed by a director in such form and verified in such with the Registrar that every subscriber to the memorandum has paid the value of the shares agreed to be taken by him and the paid-up share capital of the company is not less than five lakh rupees in case of a public company and not less than one lakh rupees in case of a private company on the date of making of this declaration; and ( b ) the company has filed with the Registrar a verification of its registered office as provided in sub-section (2) of section 12. 21 (2) If any default is made in complying with the requirements of this section, the company shall be liable to a penalty which may extend to five thousand rupees and every officer who is in default shall be punishable with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees for every day during which the default continues. (3) Where no declaration has been filed with the Registrar under clause ( a ) of sub-section (1) within a period of one hundred and eighty days of the date of incorporation of the company and the Registrar has reasonable cause to believe that the company is not carrying on any business or operations, he may, without prejudice to the provisions of sub-section (2), initiate action for the removal of the name of the company from the register of companies under Chapter XVIII. ( b ) the company has filed with the Registrar a verification of its registered office as provided in sub-section (2) of section 12. 21

(2) If any default is made in complying with the requirements of this section, the company shall be liable to a penalty which may extend to five thousand rupees and every officer who is in default shall be punishable with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees for every day during which the default continues.

(3) Where no declaration has been filed with the Registrar under clause ( a ) of sub-section (1) within a period of one hundred and eighty days of the date of incorporation of the company and the Registrar has reasonable cause to believe that the company is not carrying on any business or operations, he may, without prejudice to the provisions of sub-section (2), initiate action for the removal of the name of the company from the register of companies under Chapter XVIII.

Section 11 is Omitted vide Companies (Amendment) Act, 2015 (21 of 2015), notified on 26th May, 2015, with effect from 29th May 2015 vide notification S.O. 1440(E). 

 and Form No. INC 21 of the Companies (Incorporation) Rules,2014.
chunks.summary: A company with share capital must file a declaration verifying payment and paid-up capital before commencing business or borrowing powers. Failure to comply results in penalties, including fines on default. If no declaration is filed within 180 days after incorporation without reasonable cause, the Registrar can remove the company's name from the register.

chunks.title: Registered office of company
chunks.summary: The entity is required to have a registered office with specific conditions for International Financial Services Centers (IFSC) and their licensed operating zones. This includes specifying the zone location and operational license requirements. The company must provide proof of its registered office within a stipulated period, ensuring compliance with legal documentation.

chunks.title: Registered office of company - Subsection 1 Clause 1
chunks.text: (1) A shall, on and from the fifteenth day of its incorporation and at all times thereafter, have a registered office capable of receiving and acknowledging all communications and notices as may be addressed to it. a Specified IFSC shall have its registered office at the International Financial Services Centre located in the approved multi services Special Economic Zone set-up under the Special Economic Zones Act, 2005 read with the Special Economic Zones Rules, 2006, where it is licensed to operate, at all times. a Specified IFSC private company shall have its registered office at the International Financial Services Centre located in the approved multi services Special Economic Zone set-up under the Special Economic Zones Act, 2005 read with the Special Economic Zones Rules, 2006, where it is licensed to operate, at all times.”. (2) The company shall furnish to the verification of its registered office within a period of of its incorporation in such (3) Every company shall—
chunks.summary: A shall have a registered office capable of receiving and acknowledging communications and notices addressed to it, located at the International Financial Services Centre approved by the Special Economic Zones Act, 2005 read with the Special Economic Zones Rules, 2006. A specified IFSC private company must also have its registered office in this location.

It also requires giving notice to the Registrar within fifteen days after any change in the registered office's location, except when a special resolution is passed by the company itself.

chunks.title: Registered office of company - Subsection 1 Clause a
chunks.text: (a) in the case of an existing company, outside the local limits of any city, town or village where such office is situated at the commencement of this Act or where it may be situated later by virtue of a special resolution passed by the company; and
chunks.summary: An existing company's office must be located outside the local jurisdiction of cities, towns, or villages when the law comes into effect. This applies even if the office moves to a different location due to a special resolution later on.

chunks.title: Registered office of company - Subsection 1 Clause b
chunks.text: (b) in the case of any other company, outside the local limits of any city, town or village where such office is first situated or where it may be situated later by virtue of a special resolution passed by the company: Provided that no company shall change the place of its registered office from the jurisdiction of one Registrar to the jurisdiction of another Registrar within the same State unless such change is confirmed by the Regional Director on an application made in this behalf by the company in the (6) The confirmation referred to in sub-section (5) shall be communicated within a period of thirty days from the date of receipt of application by the Regional Director to the company and the company shall file the confirmation with the Registrar within a period of sixty days of the date of confirmation who shall register the same and certify the registration within a period of thirty days from the date of filing of such confirmation. (7) The certificate referred to in sub-section (6) shall be conclusive evidence that all the requirements of this Act with respect to change of registered office in pursuance of sub-section (5) have been complied with and the change shall take effect from the date of the certificate. (8) If any default is made in complying with the requirements of this section, the company and every shall be liable to a penalty of one thousand rupees for every day during which the default continues but not exceeding one lakh rupees. If the Registrar has reasonable cause to believe that the company is not carrying on any business or operations, he may cause a physical verification of the registered office of the company in such manner as may be prescribed and if any default is found to be made in complying with the requirements of sub-section (1), he may without prejudice to the provisions of sub-section (8), initiate action for the removal of the name of the company from the register of companies under Chapter XVIII.
chunks.summary: The text outlines strict rules regarding changes to a company's registered office, specifying that such changes must be confirmed by the Regional Director and filed with the Registrar within specified timeframes. The confirmation is conclusive evidence for compliance with the Act, and failure to comply can result in penalties of up to one lakh rupees per day. Physical verification may also be required if there are defaults found regarding sub-section (1).

The summary is as follows:

Persons acting in accordance with advice or instructions given to them by the Board of Directors are exempted from liability for contraventions under this Act unless they object to such proceedings or consent to or connive at the violation. Share transfer agents, registrars, and merchant bankers must comply with the Companies (Amendment) Act, 2019 dated July 31, 2019, effective November 2, 2018.

This text outlines specific provisions regarding directors' responsibilities and actions related to a company's amendments under the Companies (Amendment) Act, 2019. chunks.text:
(3) Every company shall—

( a ) paint or affix its name, and the address of its registered office, and keep the same painted or affixed, on the outside of every office or place in which its business is carried on, in a conspicuous position, in legible letters, and if the characters employed therefor are not those of the language or of one of the languages in general use in that locality, also in the characters of that language or of one of those languages;

( b ) have its name engraved in legible characters on its seal ;

( c ) get its name, address of its registered office and the Corporate Identity Number along with telephone number, fax number, if any, e-mail and website addresses, if any, printed in all its business letters, billheads, letter papers and in all its notices and other official publications; and

chunks.summary: Every company must paint or affix its name and address on visible parts of offices, with legible letters. It should also engrave its name on a seal and print it in the language used locally. Companies need to include their name, registered office details, Corporate Identity Number, contact information (phone, fax, email), and website addresses in all business documents. If names have changed within the last two years, they must be noted alongside the current name.

chunks.title: Registered office of company - Subsection 5 Clause i
chunks.text: (i) whole-time director; ( ii ) key managerial personnel; ( iii ) where there is no key managerial personnel, such director or directors as specified by the Board in this behalf and who has or have given his or their consent in writing to the Board to such specification, or all the directors, if no director is so specified; ( iv ) any person who, under the immediate authority of the Board or any key managerial personnel, is charged with any responsibility including maintenance, filing or distribution of accounts or records, authorises, actively participates in, knowingly permits, or knowingly fails to take active steps to prevent, any default;
chunks.summary: The text specifies who qualifies as a whole-time director: key managerial personnel, specified directors not listed but with written consent, or all directors if no specific list is provided. It defines individuals responsible for maintaining, filing, and distributing accounts or records under the Board's authority, including those who authorize, participate in, permit, or fail to prevent any default.

chunks.title: Registered office of company - Subsection 5 Clause v
chunks.text: (v) any person in accordance with whose advice, directions or instructions the Board of Directors of the company is accustomed to act, other than a person who gives advice to the Board in a professional capacity; ( vi ) every director, in respect of a contravention of any of the provisions of this Act, who is aware of such contravention by virtue of the receipt by him of any proceedings of the Board or participation in such proceedings without objecting to the same, or where such contravention had taken place with his consent or connivance; ( vii ) in respect of the issue or transfer of any shares of a company, the share transfer agents, registrars and merchant bankers to the issue or transfer
chunks.summary:
The summary is as follows:

Persons acting on advice, directions, or instructions from the Board's directors without objection or consent are exempted. Directors who fail to object to Board proceedings or participate in them without objection or consent may be held liable for contraventions of this Act. Share transfer agents, registrars, and merchant bankers involved in share issues or transfers must comply with relevant regulations.

chunks.title: Registered office of company - Subsection 5 Clause i
chunks.summary:
The summary should be concise and factual, avoiding legal jargon. Here's a simplified version:

"Directors who meet specific criteria are defined: whole-time directors, key managerial personnel, or those specified by the Board with consent."

chunks.title: Registered office of company - Subsection 5 Clause v
chunks.summary:
The summary is as follows:

This text specifies that directors must act according to advice or instructions given by them, unless they object to such actions or know of a violation without objection. It also requires share transfer agents and registrars to comply with the Companies (Amendment) Act, 2019 dated July 31, 2019 effective November 2, 2018.

chunks.title: Alteration of memorandum
chunks.summary: This section outlines procedures for amending a company's name and memorandum. It specifies that amendments to the company's name must be approved by resolution followed by compliance with specific requirements as detailed in sections 4 and 5. The new name entry process ensures complete effectiveness of the change on issuance of a new certificate of incorporation, which is optional only if the sole alteration involves removing or adding the word 'Private'. Additionally, it clarifies that changes made under section 2 do not affect the registered office unless specified in this clause.

chunks.title: Alteration of memorandum - Subsection 1 Clause 1
chunks.text: (1) Save as provided in section 61, a may, by a special resolution and after complying with the procedure specified in this section, the provisions of its . (2) Any change in the name of a company shall be subject to the provisions of sub-sections (2) and (3) of section 4 and shall not have effect except with the approval of the Provided that no such approval shall be necessary where the only change in the name of the company is the deletion therefrom, or addition thereto, of the word “Private”, consequent on the conversion of any one class of companies to another class in accordance with the provisions of this Act. (3) When any change in the name of a company is made under sub-section (2), the shall enter the new name in the in place of the old name and issue a fresh certificate of incorporation with the new name and the change in the name shall be complete and effective only on the issue of such a certificate. (4) The alteration of the memorandum relating to the place of the registered office from one State to another shall not have any effect unless it is approved by the on an application in such as (5) The shall dispose of the application under sub-section (4) within a period of sixty days and before passing its order may satisfy itself that the alteration has the consent of the creditors, -holders and other persons concerned with the company or that the sufficient provision has been made by the company either for the due discharge of all its debts and obligations or that adequate security has been provided for such discharge. (6) Save as provided in section 64, a company shall, in relation to any alteration of its memorandum, file with the Registrar—

The new name must be entered into the register and accompanied by a fresh certificate of incorporation upon issuance. Alterations to the registered office address require approval from relevant authorities within 60 days, and creditors' consent is necessary for such applications.

chunks.title: Alteration of articles
chunks.summary: The Companies (Amendment) Act, 2019 allows a company to convert from private to public status through specific legal procedures and approvals. Any conversion must comply with specified requirements; alterations altering a private company into a public one without Government approval are not valid. Pending applications prior to the Act’s commencement date will be handled by the Tribunal.

chunks.title: Alteration of articles - Subsection 1 Clause b
chunks.text: (b) a public company into a private company: Provided that where a company being a private company alters its articles in such a manner that they no longer include the restrictions and limitations which are required to be included in the articles of a private company under this Act, the company shall, as from the date of such alteration, cease to be a private company: any alteration having the effect of conversion of a public company into a private company shall not be valid unless it is approved by an order of the Central Government on an application made in such form and manner as may be prescribed: any application pending before the Tribunal, as on the date of commencement of the Companies (Amendment) Act, 2019, shall be disposed of by the Tribunal in accordance with the provisions applicable to it before such commencement. any alteration having the effect of conversion of a public company into a private company shall not be valid unless it is approved by an order of the on an application made in such form and manner : Provided also that any application pending before the Tribunal, as on the date of commencement of the Companies (Amendment) Ordinance, 2018 , shall be disposed of by the Tribunal in accordance with the provisions applicable to it before such commencement. Provided further that any alteration having the effect of conversion of a public company into a private company shall not take effect except with the approval of the which shall make such order as it may deem fit. (2) Every alteration of the articles under this section and a copy of the order of the Tribunal approving the alteration as per sub-section (1) , together with a printed copy of the altered articles, within a period of fifteen days in who shall register the same. (3) Any alteration of the articles registered under sub-section (2) shall, subject to the provisions of this Act, be valid as if it were originally in the articles.
chunks.summary: A public company can convert into a private company provided its articles no longer include required restrictions. Such conversion must be approved by the Central Government or Tribunal on an application following prescribed form and manner. Pending applications before the Tribunal will be handled according to applicable provisions prior to the Act's commencement. Any alteration affecting public-to-private conversion requires approval, with the authority making such order as deemed fit. Articles' alterations need registration within 15 days of registration.

chunks.title: Alteration of articles - Subsection 1
chunks.text:
(1) Subject to the provisions of this Act and the conditions contained in its , if any, a may, by a special resolution, its including alterations having the effect of conversion of—

( a ) a into a ; or

( b ) a public company into a private company:

Provided that where a company being a private company alters its articles in such a manner that they no longer include the restrictions and limitations which are required to be included in the articles of a private company under this Act, the company shall, as from the date of such alteration, cease to be a private company:

any alteration having the effect of conversion of a public company into a private company shall not be valid unless it is approved by an order of the Central Government on an application made in such form and manner as may be prescribed:

any application pending before the Tribunal, as on the date of commencement of the Companies (Amendment) Act, 2019, shall be disposed of by the Tribunal in accordance with the provisions applicable to it before such commencement.

any alteration having the effect of conversion of a public company into a private company shall not be valid unless it is approved by an order of the on an application made in such form and manner :

Provided also that any application pending before the Tribunal, as on the date of commencement of the Companies (Amendment) Ordinance, 2018 , shall be disposed of by the Tribunal in accordance with the provisions applicable to it before such commencement.

Provided further that any alteration having the effect of conversion of a public company into a private company shall not take effect except with the approval of the which shall make such order as it may deem fit.

It specifies that such conversions require special resolutions and must be approved by the Central Government or an appropriate authority, depending on the date of commencement. chunks.title: Alteration of memorandum or articles to be noted in every copy
chunks.summary: The memorandum and articles must be noted in every copy issued without alteration. Companies defaulting on compliance face penalties for each unaltered copy. Alterations include additions, omissions, and substitutions. Articles are defined as originally framed or altered from time to time. Directors fall under specific categories based on their authority: whole-time directors, key managerial personnel, specified by the Board, or others acting in accordance with Board advice.

chunks.title: Rectification of name of company
chunks.summary: Regulation 45 of LODR (1) stipulates that upon the initial registration or subsequent change in name, a company must rectify its name if it is identical with or too closely resembling another registered company's name. The company needs to do this within three months after receiving a direction from an authority and obtain an ordinary resolution for the purpose. For trade marks, companies are required to notify the Central Government within three years of incorporation or changing their name.

chunks.title: Rectification of name of company - Subsection 1
chunks.summary: If a company's registered name is identical with or too similar to another existing company's registered name under trade marks law, it must change its name within three months if directed by the Central Government. If a trade mark owner applies within three years of incorporation or registration, they can also require a name change within six months.

chunks.title: Rectification of name of company - Subsection 2
chunks.text:
(2) Where a company changes its name or obtains a new name under sub-section (1), it shall within a period of fifteen days from the date of such change, give notice of the change to the along with the order of the Central Government, who shall carry out necessary changes in the certificate of incorporation and the .

If a company is in default in complying with any direction given under sub-section (1), the Central Government shall allot a new name to the company in such manner as may be prescribed and the Registrar shall enter the new name in the register of companies in place of the old name and issue a fresh certificate of incorporation with the new name, which the company shall use thereafter:

Provided that nothing in this sub-section shall prevent a company from subsequently changing its name in accordance with the provisions of section 13.
chunks.summary: A company must notify the Central Government within fifteen days after changing its name or obtaining a new one under Subsection (1). The government will then make necessary changes to the certificate and register. If a company fails to comply, it can receive a new name as prescribed by law, with the updated information entered into the register and a fresh incorporation certificate issued. This provision allows for future name changes without violating this rule.

The General Circular 04/2017 and notifications S.O. 4090(E) provide clarifications on delegation of powers to Regional Directors in Mumbai, Kolkata, Chennai, New Delhi, Ahmedabad, Hyderabad, and Shillong.

chunks.title: Rectification of name of company - Subsection 3 Clause i
chunks.text: (i) whole-time director; ( ii ) key managerial personnel; ( iii ) where there is no key managerial personnel, such director or directors as specified by the Board in this behalf and who has or have given his or their consent in writing to the Board to such specification, or all the directors, if no director is so specified; ( iv ) any person who, under the immediate authority of the Board or any key managerial personnel, is charged with any responsibility including maintenance, filing or distribution of accounts or records, authorises, actively participates in, knowingly permits, or knowingly fails to take active steps to prevent, any default;
chunks.summary: The text specifies who qualifies as a whole-time director: key managerial personnel, specified directors not listed but with written consent, or all directors if no specific are listed. It defines individuals responsible for maintaining, filing, and distributing accounts or records under the Board's authority, including those who authorize, participate in, permit, or fail to prevent default.

chunks.title: Rectification of name of company - Subsection 3 Clause v
chunks.text: (v) any person in accordance with whose advice, directions or instructions the Board of Directors of the company is accustomed to act, other than a person who gives advice to the Board in a professional capacity; ( vi ) every director, in respect of a contravention of any of the provisions of this Act, who is aware of such contravention by virtue of the receipt by him of any proceedings of the Board or participation in such proceedings without objecting to the same, or where such contravention had taken place with his consent or connivance; ( vii ) in respect of the issue or transfer of any shares of a company, the share transfer agents, registrars and merchant bankers to the issue or transfer
chunks.summary:
The summary is as follows:

Persons acting on advice, directions, or instructions customary with the board's actions are exempted. Directors who know about contraventions but fail to object or consent without objection are also exempted. Share transfer agents, registrars, and merchant bankers involved in share issues or transfers must comply with this regulation.

chunks.title: Rectification of name of company - Subsection 3 Clause i
chunks.summary: The text specifies who qualifies as a whole-time director: key managerial personnel, specified directors not listed, or those directly under immediate Board authority. It also defines individuals responsible for maintaining, filing, and distributing accounts or records, including their duties to prevent defaults.

chunks.title: Rectification of name of company - Subsection 3 Clause v
chunks.summary:
The summary is as follows:

This text specifies that directors must comply with Board advice, even if they do not object to proceedings initiated by the Board. It also requires directors involved in share issues or transfers to act according to instructions from share agents and bankers without objection or consent.

chunks.summary: A company registered under this Act may convert to another class by amending its articles and complying with Chapter provisions. Where required, a company must close its previous registration upon application, register as per the chapter's requirements, and issue a new certificate of incorporation in the same manner as its initial registration. The conversion does not affect pre-existing debts, liabilities, obligations, or contracts before the change.

chunks.title: Subsidiary company not to hold shares in its holding company
chunks.summary: Under this section, shareholders are prohibited from holding or transferring shares in their parent company. This restriction applies to companies not involving cases where a subsidiary holds shares on behalf of a deceased parent or as a trustee. The right to vote is limited for the shareholder's right during the period of legal representation or trust. No provision allows the transfer or allotment of shares if it would violate this section.

chunks.title: Subsidiary company not to hold shares in its holding company - Subsection 1
chunks.text: (1) No company shall, either by itself or through its nominees, hold any in its holding company and no shall allot or transfer its shares to any of its and any such allotment or transfer of shares of a company to its subsidiary company shall be void: Provided that nothing in this sub-section shall apply to a case— ( a ) where the subsidiary company holds such shares as the legal representative of a deceased of the holding company; or ( b ) where the subsidiary company holds such shares as a trustee; or ( c ) where the subsidiary company is a shareholder even before it became a subsidiary company of the holding company: Provided further that the subsidiary company referred to in the preceding proviso shall have a right to vote at a meeting of the holding company only in respect of the shares held by it as a legal representative or as a trustee, as referred to in clause ( a ) or clause ( b ) of the said proviso. (2) The reference in this section to the shares of a holding company which is a or an , not having a share capital, shall be construed as a reference to the interest of its members, whatever be the form of interest.
chunks.summary: No person may hold any shares in their own company through nominees. Allotments and transfers of shares by holding companies to subsidiaries are void unless specifically permitted under certain conditions: legal representatives or trustees can receive shares as such, but only for voting rights related to those roles. The reference to a shareholding company without capital applies to members' interests regardless of interest form.

chunks.title: Subsidiary company not to hold shares in its holding company - Subsection 1
chunks.text:
(1) No company shall, either by itself or through its nominees, hold any in its holding company and no shall allot or transfer its shares to any of its and any such allotment or transfer of shares of a company to its subsidiary company shall be void:

Provided that nothing in this sub-section shall apply to a case—

( a ) where the subsidiary company holds such shares as the legal representative of a deceased of the holding company; or

( b ) where the subsidiary company holds such shares as a trustee; or

( c ) where the subsidiary company is a shareholder even before it became a subsidiary company of the holding company:

Provided further that the subsidiary company referred to in the preceding proviso shall have a right to vote at a meeting of the holding company only in respect of the shares held by it as a legal representative or as a trustee, as referred to in clause ( a ) or clause ( b ) of the said proviso.
chunks.summary: The text prohibits companies from holding shares through nominees and requires allotments or transfers of shares within their subsidiaries to be void. It allows exceptions for cases where the subsidiary holds shares as legal representatives of deceased companies, trustees, or pre-existing shareholders before becoming a subsidiary. The subsidiary can only vote on behalf of these shares at holding company meetings.

chunks.title: Subsidiary company not to hold shares in its holding company - Subsection 2 Clause i
chunks.text: (i) controls the composition of the Board of Directors; or (ii) exercises or controls more than one-half of the total voting power either at its own or together with one or more of its subsidiary companies: Provided that such class or classes of holding companies as may be prescribed shall not have layers of subsidiaries beyond such numbers  as may be prescribed. chunks.summary: This clause specifies that a company must control either the entire Board of Directors or more than half of the total voting power in its own and subsidiary companies. It also states that such holding companies cannot have layers of subsidiaries beyond those prescribed by law.

chunks.title: Authentication of documents, proceedings and contracts
chunks.summary: The text specifies that certain documents, including those requiring authentication by a company, can be signed by authorized officers of the company. These include the Chief Executive Officer, managing director, manager, company secretary, whole-time directors, Chief Financial Officers, and up to one level below them designated as key managerial personnel. The amendments also allow for other employees to sign documents if they are in full-time employment and have been designated by the Board.

chunks.title: Execution of bills of exchange, etc.
chunks.text:
(1) A bill of exchange, hundi or promissory note shall be deemed to have been made, accepted, drawn or endorsed on behalf of a if made, accepted, drawn, or endorsed in the name of, or on behalf of or on account of, the company by any person acting under its authority, express or implied. (2) A company may, by writing under its common seal , authorise any person, either generally or in respect of any specified matters, as its attorney to execute other deeds on its behalf in any place either in or outside India. (3) A deed signed by such an attorney on behalf of the company and under his seal shall bind the company

This amendment took effect from May 29, 2015, following a notification dated May 26, 2015.

chunks.title: Public offer and private placement
chunks.summary: Regulation 32 of LODR (1) authorizes issuers to issue securities through public offerings and private placements in accordance with specified conditions. It also provides a rights issue or bonus issue for certain companies, including those seeking listing on foreign exchanges as per the India Act, 1992, and its rules. The regulation emphasizes compliance under this Act, potentially affecting multiple areas such as MOA/AAO alteration, share capital issues, and registration of securities.

chunks.title: Public offer and private placement - Subsection 1
chunks.text:
(1) A may issue —

( a ) to public through (herein referred to as “public offer”) by complying with the provisions of this Part; or

( b ) through private placement by complying with the provisions of Part II of this Chapter; or (Effective from 01-04-2014)

( c ) through a rights issue or a bonus issue in accordance with the provisions of this Act and in case of a or a company which intends to get its securities listed also with the provisions of the of India Act, 1992 (15 of 1992) and the rules and regulations made thereunder.
chunks.summary: A may issue securities through public offer, private placement, rights issue/bonus issue, or in accordance with the provisions of the Indian Act, 1992. Effective from April 1, 2014.

chunks.text: (2) A may issue securities—

chunks.title: Public offer and private placement - Subsection 2 Clause b
chunks.text:
(b) through private placement by complying with the provisions of Part II of this Chapter.(Effective from 01-04-2014)

Explanation .—For the purposes of this Chapter, “public offer” includes initial public offer or further public offer of securities to the public by a company, or an offer for sale of securities to the public by an existing shareholder, through issue of a prospectus .
chunks.summary: The text specifies that private placements must comply with Part II of Chapter, effective from 01-04-2014. "Public offers" include initial or further public offerings to the general public by companies or shareholders selling securities through a prospectus.

chunks.summary: A minimum paid-up share capital applies to companies as prescribed. Subsidiaries of non-private companies are considered public companies under this act, provided they remain private in their articles.
