chunks.summary: The text restricts the right to transfer shares and limits One Person Company membership to two hundred members. It also prohibits public subscriptions for company securities, with certain exceptions for employees and former employees of the company. The amendments are effective as per MCA Notifications dated 30 October 2023, yet not yet notified under Companies (Amendment) Act, 2020.

chunks.title: Power of Securities and Exchange Board to regulate issue and transfer of securities, etc.
chunks.text:
Regulation 28 of LODR (1) The provisions contained in this Chapter, Chapter IV and in section 127 shall,— ( a ) in so far as they relate to — ( i ) issue and transfer of ; and ( ii ) non-payment of dividend, by listed companies or those companies which intend to get their securities listed on any in India, except as provided under this Act, be administered by the by making regulations in this behalf; ( b ) in any other case, be administered by the Central Government. Explanation .—For the removal of doubts, it is hereby declared that all powers relating to all other matters relating to , return of allotment, redemption of preference and any other matter specifically provided in this Act, shall be exercised by the Central Government, or the , as the case may be. (2) The Securities and Exchange Board shall, in respect of matters specified in sub-section (1) and the matters delegated to it under proviso to sub-section (1) of section 458, exercise the powers conferred upon it under sub-sections (1), (2A), (3) and (4) of section 11, sections 11A, 11B and 11D of the Securities and Exchange Board of India Act, 1992 (15 of 1992). 

Regulation 28 of LODR

(1) The provisions contained in this Chapter, Chapter IV and in section 127 shall,—

( a ) in so far as they relate to —

( i ) issue and transfer of ; and

( ii ) non-payment of dividend,

by listed companies or those companies which intend to get their securities listed on any in India, except as provided under this Act, be administered by the by making regulations in this behalf;

( b ) in any other case, be administered by the Central Government.

Explanation .—For the removal of doubts, it is hereby declared that all powers relating to all other matters relating to , return of allotment, redemption of preference and any other matter specifically provided in this Act, shall be exercised by the Central Government, or the , as the case may be.

(2) The Securities and Exchange Board shall, in respect of matters specified in sub-section (1) and the matters delegated to it under proviso to sub-section (1) of section 458, exercise the powers conferred upon it under sub-sections (1), (2A), (3) and (4) of section 11, sections 11A, 11B and 11D of the Securities and Exchange Board of India Act, 1992 (15 of 1992).

Until Tribunal (NCLT) is setup, Company Law Board shall exercise power under this section vide notification S.O. 1459(E).
chunks.summary: The provisions in Chapter, Chapter IV, and section 127 of LODR are administered by the Central Government except as provided in this Act. For other matters not covered by this Act, powers will be exercised by the Central Government or the Company Law Board as per the Securities and Exchange Board of India Act, 1992 (S.O. 1459(E)).

chunks.title: Document containing offer of securities for sale to be deemed prospectus
chunks.text:
(1) Where a allots or agrees to allot any of the company with a view to all or any of those securities being offered for sale to the public, any by which the offer for sale to the public is made shall, for all purposes, be deemed to be a issued by the company; and all enactments and rules of law as to the contents of prospectus and as to liability in respect of mis-statements, in and omissions from, prospectus, or otherwise relating to prospectus, shall apply with the modifications specified in sub-sections (3) and (4) and shall have effect accordingly, as if the securities had been offered to the public for subscription and as if persons accepting the offer in respect of any securities were subscribers for those securities, but without prejudice to the liability, if any, of the persons by whom the offer is made in respect of mis-statements contained in the document or otherwise in respect thereof. (2) For the purposes of this Act, it shall, unless the contrary is proved, be evidence that an allotment of, or an agreement to allot, securities was made with a view to the securities being offered for sale to the public if it is shown— ( a ) that an offer of the securities or of any of them for sale to the public was made within six months after the allotment or agreement to allot; or ( b ) that at the date when the offer was made, the whole consideration to be received by the company in respect of the securities had not been received by it. (3) Section 26 as applied by this section shall have effect as if — ( i ) it required a prospectus to state in addition to the matters required by that section to be stated in a prospectus— ( a ) the net amount of the consideration received or to be received by the company in respect of the securities to which the offer relates; and ( b ) the time and place at which the contract where under the said securities have been or are to be allotted may be inspected; ( ii ) the persons making the offer were persons named in a prospectus as of a company.(Effective from 01-04-2014) (4) Where a person making an offer to which this section relates is a company or a firm, it shall be sufficient if the document referred to in sub-section (1) is signed on behalf of the company or firm by two directors of the company or by not less than one-half of the partners in the firm, as the case may be. 

(1) Where a allots or agrees to allot any of the company with a view to all or any of those securities being offered for sale to the public, any by which the offer for sale to the public is made shall, for all purposes, be deemed to be a issued by the company; and all enactments and rules of law as to the contents of prospectus and as to liability in respect of mis-statements, in and omissions from, prospectus, or otherwise relating to prospectus, shall apply with the modifications specified in sub-sections (3) and (4) and shall have effect accordingly, as if the securities had been offered to the public for subscription and as if persons accepting the offer in respect of any securities were subscribers for those securities, but without prejudice to the liability, if any, of the persons by whom the offer is made in respect of mis-statements contained in the document or otherwise in respect thereof.

(2) For the purposes of this Act, it shall, unless the contrary is proved, be evidence that an allotment of, or an agreement to allot, securities was made with a view to the securities being offered for sale to the public if it is shown—

( a ) that an offer of the securities or of any of them for sale to the public was made within six months after the allotment or agreement to allot; or

( b ) that at the date when the offer was made, the whole consideration to be received by the company in respect of the securities had not been received by it.

(3) Section 26 as applied by this section shall have effect as if —

( i ) it required a prospectus to state in addition to the matters required by that section to be stated in a prospectus—

( a ) the net amount of the consideration received or to be received by the company in respect of the securities to which the offer relates; and

( b ) the time and place at which the contract where under the said securities have been or are to be allotted may be inspected;

( ii ) the persons making the offer were persons named in a prospectus as of a company.(Effective from 01-04-2014)

(4) Where a person making an offer to which this section relates is a company or a firm, it shall be sufficient if the document referred to in sub-section (1) is signed on behalf of the company or firm by two directors of the company or by not less than one-half of the partners in the firm, as the case may be.
chunks.summary: Where a company allots or agrees to allot any of its securities with the intention of offering them for sale to the public, such allotment is deemed an issue by the company. All enactments and rules regarding prospectuses apply with specified modifications, treating the securities as offered for subscription instead of direct sale.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus
chunks.summary: Issued documents by or on behalf of a public company must include detailed information about registered offices, board members, opening and closing dates of the issue, details about monies received, consent from directors and auditors, and provisions for issue acceptance. The document is dated and signed with specific requirements that affect the separate bank account for funds transferred and disclose details of previous issues.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause 1
chunks.text: (1) Every issued by or on behalf of a either with reference to its formation or subsequently, or by or on behalf of any person who is or has been engaged or interested in the formation of a public company, shall be dated and signed and shall— state the
chunks.summary: Issued documents related to public companies must include dates, signatures, and specify the formation date.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause i
chunks.text: (i) names and addresses of the registered office of the company, Company Secretary , Chief Financial Officer , auditors, legal advisers, bankers, trustees, if any, underwriters and such other persons ( ii ) dates of the opening and closing of the issue, and declaration about the issue of allotment letters and refunds within the ( iii ) a statement by the Board of Director s a bout the separate bank account where all monies received out of the issue are to be transferred and disclosure of details of all monies including utilised and unutilised monies out of the previous issue in the ( iv ) details about
chunks.summary: The document specifies names, addresses, dates, statements from directors, bank account details, and information regarding a company's past issues.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause v
chunks.text: (v) consent of the directors , auditors, bankers to the issue, expert’s opinion, if any, and of such other persons, ( vi ) the authority for the issue and the details of the resolution passed therefor; ( vii ) procedure and time schedule for allotment and issue of securities (viii ) capital structure of the company in the prescribed manner; ( ix ) main objects of public offer, terms of the present issue and such other particulars
chunks.summary: The text specifies that consent from directors, auditors, bankers, experts' opinion, resolution details, allotment procedure, capital structure, and main objectives must be provided for a public offering.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause x
chunks.text: (x) main objects and present business of the company and its location, schedule of implementation of the project; (xi)particulars relating to— ( A ) management perception of risk factors specific to the project; ( B ) gestation period of the project; ( C ) extent of progress made in the project; ( D ) deadlines for completion of the project; and ( E ) any litigation or legal action pending or taken by a Government Department or a statutory body during the last five years immediately preceding the year of the issue of prospectus against the promoter of the company; (xii)minimum subscription, amount payable by way of premium, issue of shares otherwise than on cash; (xiii)d etails of directors including their appointments and , and such particulars of the nature and extent of their interests in the company and (xiv)disclosures in such manner about sources of promoter’s contribution; set out the following reports for the purposes of the financial information, namely:—
chunks.summary: The document outlines key elements related to a company's prospectus. It specifies details on management perceptions regarding project risks, gestation periods, progress made, completion deadlines, and any pending or past legal actions against the company promoter over the last five years. Additionally, it requires minimum subscription amounts for shares not paid in cash, directors' appointments, their interests, and disclosures about contributions sources from promoters.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause i
chunks.text: (i) reports by the auditors of the company with respect to its profits and losses and assets and liabilities and such other matters ( ii ) reports relating to profits and losses for each of the five immediately preceding the financial year of the issue of prospectus including such reports of its and in such manner Provided that in case of a company with respect to which a period of five years has not elapsed from the date of incorporation, the prospectus shall set out in such manner , the reports relating to profits and losses for each of the financial years immediately preceding the financial year of the issue of prospectus including such reports of its subsidiaries; ( iii ) reports made in the by the auditors upon the profits and losses of the business of the company for each of the five financial years immediately preceding issue and assets and liabilities of its business on the last date to which the accounts of the business were made up, being a date not more than one hundred and eighty days before the issue of the prospectus: Provided that in case of a company with respect to which a period of five years has not elapsed from the date of incorporation, the prospectus shall set out in the prescribed manner, the reports made by the auditors upon the profits and losses of the business of the company for all financial years from the date of its incorporation, and assets and liabilities of its business on the last date before the issue of prospectus; and ( iv ) reports about the business or transaction to which the proceeds of the securities are to be applied directly or indirectly;
chunks.summary: The text specifies that companies must provide auditors' reports detailing profits, losses, assets, liabilities, and subsidiary reports for five financial years preceding the prospectus issue. For incorporation periods exceeding five years, these details must also include reports on business operations and assets up to one hundred eighty days prior to the prospectus issuance.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause c
chunks.text: (c) make a declaration about the compliance of the provisions of this Act and a statement to the effect that nothing in the prospectus is contrary to the provisions of this Act, the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956 (42 of 1956) and the of India Act, 1992 (15 of 1992) and the rules and regulations made thereunder; and state such other matters and set out such other reports, (2) Nothing in sub-section (1) shall apply—
chunks.summary: The entity must declare compliance with this Act's provisions. It also states that nothing in the prospectus is contrary to these laws, regulations, or rules.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause a
chunks.text: (a) to the issue to existing or debenture-holders of a company, of a prospectus or form of application relating to shares in or of the company, whether an applicant has a right to renounce the shares or not under sub-clause ( ii ) of clause
chunks.summary: The text states that it pertains to existing or debenture-holders of a company regarding prospectuses or applications related to their shares. It specifies that an applicant has a right to renounce the shares if they do not meet certain conditions under sub-clause (ii) of clause.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause b
chunks.text: (b) to the issue of a prospectus or form of application relating to shares or debentures which are, or are to be, in all respects uniform with shares or debentures previously issued and for the time being dealt in or quoted on a . (3) Subject to sub-section (2), the provisions of sub-section (1) shall apply to a prospectus or a form of application, whether issued on or with reference to the formation of a company or subsequently. Explanation .—The date indicated in the prospectus shall be deemed to be the date of its publication. (4) No prospectus shall be issued by or on behalf of a company or in relation to an intended company unless on or before the date of its publication, there has been delivered to the for registration , a copy thereof signed by every person who is named therein as a director or proposed director of the company or by his duly authorised attorney. (5) A prospectus issued under sub-section (1) shall not include a statement purporting to be made by an expert unless the expert is a person who is not, and has not been, engaged or interested in the formation or promotion or management, of the company and has given his written consent to the issue of the prospectus and has not withdrawn such consent before the delivery of a copy of the prospectus to the Registrar for registration and a statement to that effect shall be included in the prospectus. (6) Every prospectus issued under sub-section (1) shall, on the face of it,—
chunks.summary:
The summary is as follows:

(b) The prospectus or form of application must comply with shares or debentures previously issued and quoted on a recognized stock exchange. It applies to both initial company formation and subsequent issues.

(4) A company must deliver copies signed by directors or proposed directors before publication.

(5) Expert statements in the prospectus cannot be made by engaged parties, requiring consent from experts who have not withdrawn their approval.

(6) The prospectus should clearly state its date of publication.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause a
chunks.text: (a) state that a copy has been delivered for registration to the Registrar as required under sub-section (4); and
chunks.summary: The document requires delivery of a copy for registration with the Registrar, in accordance with Subsection 4.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause b
chunks.text: (b) specify any required by this section to be attached to the copy so delivered or refer to statements included in the prospectus which specify these documents. The Registrar shall not register a prospectus unless the requirements of this section with respect to its registration are complied with and the prospectus is accompanied by the consent in writing of all the persons named in the prospectus. (8) No prospectus shall be valid if it is issued more than ninety days after the date on which a copy thereof is delivered to the Registrar under sub-section (4). (9) If a prospectus is issued in contravention of the provisions of this section, the company shall be punishable with fine which shall not be less than fifty thousand rupees but which may extend to three lakh rupees and every person who is knowingly a party to the issue of such prospectus shall be punishable with fine which shall not be less than fifty thousand rupees but which may extend to three lakh rupees, or with both .
chunks.summary: The text specifies that required documents must accompany the delivered copy and requires compliance with registration provisions. It prohibits issuance of a prospectus more than ninety days after delivery unless accompanied by consent from all named parties and punishable fines for violations.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause i
chunks.summary: The text specifies that companies must provide auditors' reports detailing profits, losses, assets, liabilities, and subsidiary reports for five financial years preceding the prospectus issue. For incorporation periods exceeding five years, these details must also include reports on the business's profits, losses, and assets from its inception until the prospectus date. Additionally, reports about how proceeds are applied to specific transactions or businesses must be included in the prospectus.

chunks.text:
(2) Nothing in sub-section (1) shall apply—

chunks.summary:
Nothing in sub-section (1) shall apply—

( a ) to existing or debenture-holders of a company regarding prospectuses or applications related to its shares, even if they have renounced their rights under clause 62(ii), unless for the same uniformity as previously issued and traded.

( b ) to prospectuses or applications concerning new shares or debentures that are identical with those already in circulation.

chunks.text:
(3) Subject to sub-section (2), the provisions of sub-section (1) shall apply to a prospectus or a form of application, whether issued on or with reference to the formation of a company or subsequently.

Explanation .—The date indicated in the prospectus shall be deemed to be the date of its publication.
chunks.summary: Sub-section (2) does not apply; sub-section (1)'s provisions apply to both pre- and post-company formation documents. The date on a prospectus is considered the publication date.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 4
chunks.text: (4) No prospectus shall be issued by or on behalf of a company or in relation to an intended company unless on or before the date of its publication, there has been delivered to the for registration , a copy thereof signed by every person who is named therein as a director or proposed director of the company or by his duly authorised attorney.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 5
chunks.text: (5) A prospectus issued under sub-section (1) shall not include a statement purporting to be made by an expert unless the expert is a person who is not, and has not been, engaged or interested in the formation or promotion or management, of the company and has given his written consent to the issue of the prospectus and has not withdrawn such consent before the delivery of a copy of the prospectus to the Registrar for registration and a statement to that effect shall be included in the prospectus.
chunks.summary: A prospectus issued under sub-section (1) must not contain statements purportedly made by an expert unless the expert is not engaged or interested in the company's formation, promotion, management, has given written consent to issue the prospectus, and such consent remains valid until the prospectus is registered with the Registrar.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 6
chunks.text:
(6) Every prospectus issued under sub-section (1) shall, on the face of it,—

( a ) state that a copy has been delivered for registration to the Registrar as required under sub-section (4); and

( b ) specify any required by this section to be attached to the copy so delivered or refer to statements included in the prospectus which specify these documents.

The Registrar shall not register a prospectus unless the requirements of this section with respect to its registration are complied with and the prospectus is accompanied by the consent in writing of all the persons named in the prospectus.
chunks.summary: Prospectuses issued under sub-section (1) must state that a copy has been delivered for registration, and specify any required documents. The Registrar will not register unless these requirements are met and accompanied by written consent from all parties listed in the prospectus.

Provided that on an application made by a company or body corporate, which is a holding company or a subsidiary of a company incorporated outside India and is required to follow a different financial year for consolidation of its accounts outside India, the Tribunal may, if it is satisfied, allow any period as its financial year, whether or not that period is a year:

chunks.title: Variation in terms of contract or objects in prospectus
chunks.text:
(1) A shall not, at any time, vary the terms of a contract referred to in the or objects for which the prospectus was issued, except subject to the approval of, or except subject to an authority given by the company in general meeting by way of special resolution: Provided that the details, of the notice in respect of such resolution to shareholders, shall also be published in the newspapers (one in English and one in vernacular language) in the city where the registered office of the company is situated indicating clearly the justification for such variation: Provided further that such company shall not use any amount raised by it through prospectus for buying, trading or otherwise dealing in equity of any other . (2) The dissenting shareholders being those shareholders who have not agreed to the proposal to vary the terms of contracts or objects referred to in the prospectus, shall be given an exit offer by or controlling shareholders at such exit price, and in such manner and conditions as may be specified by the by making regulations in this behalf.

chunks.title: Advertisement of prospectus
chunks.summary: An advertisement must specify the memorandum's contents regarding the company's objects, liability, capital, signatories' names, subscribed shares, and capital structure. The subscriber to the memorandum becomes a registered member upon registration; others who agree in writing become members through entry in the register of members or beneficial owners in depositories.

chunks.title: Shelf prospectus
chunks.text:
(1) Any class or classes of companies, as the may provide by regulations in this behalf, may file a shelf prospectus with the at the stage of the first offer of included therein which shall indicate a period not exceeding one year as the period of validity of such prospectus which shall commence from the date of opening of the first offer of securities under that prospectus, and in respect of a second or subsequent offer of such securities issued during the period of validity of that prospectus, no further is required. (2) A company filing a shelf prospectus shall be required to file an information memorandum containing all material facts relating to new created, changes in the financial position of the company as have occurred between the first offer of securities or the previous offer of securities and the succeeding offer of securities and such other changes with the Registrar within the prescribed time, prior to the issue of a second or subsequent offer of securities under the shelf prospectus: Provided that where a company or any other person has received applications for the allotment of securities along with advance payments of subscription before the making of any such change, the company or other person shall intimate the changes to such applicants and if they express a desire to withdraw their application, the company or other person shall refund all the monies received as subscription within fifteen days thereof. (3) Where an information memorandum is filed, every time an offer of securities is made under sub-section (2), such memorandum together with the shelf prospectus shall be deemed to be a prospectus. Explanation.— For the purposes of this section, the expression “shelf prospectus” means a prospectus in respect of which the securities or class of securities included therein are issued for subscription in one or more issues over a certain period without the issue of a further prospectus.

(2) A company filing a shelf prospectus shall be required to file an information memorandum containing all material facts relating to new created, changes in the financial position of the company as have occurred between the first offer of securities or the previous offer of securities and the succeeding offer of securities and such other changes with the Registrar within the prescribed time, prior to the issue of a second or subsequent offer of securities under the shelf prospectus:

Provided that where a company or any other person has received applications for the allotment of securities along with advance payments of subscription before the making of any such change, the company or other person shall intimate the changes to such applicants and if they express a desire to withdraw their application, the company or other person shall refund all the monies received as subscription within fifteen days thereof.

(3) Where an information memorandum is filed, every time an offer of securities is made under sub-section (2), such memorandum together with the shelf prospectus shall be deemed to be a prospectus.

Explanation.— For the purposes of this section, the expression “shelf prospectus” means a prospectus in respect of which the securities or class of securities included therein are issued for subscription in one or more issues over a certain period without the issue of a further prospectus.

Charge means an interest or lien created on the property or assets of a company or any of its undertakings or both as security and includes a mortgage

 of the Companies (Prospectus and Allotment of Securities) Rules,2014.
chunks.summary: Companies can file a shelf prospectus for up to one year after the first offering. Subsequent offers require only filing an information memorandum, not additional prospectuses. Companies must inform applicants of changes and refund subscription monies if withdrawn. Shelf prospectuses are defined as prospectuses for multiple issues over a period without further prospectus issuance.

chunks.title: Red herring prospectus
chunks.text:
(1) A proposing to make an offer of may issue a red herring prospectus prior to the issue of a . (2) A company proposing to issue a red herring prospectus under sub-section (1) shall file it with the at least three days prior to the opening of the subscription list and the offer. (3) A red herring prospectus shall carry the same obligations as are applicable to a prospectus and any variation between the red herring prospectus and a prospectus shall be highlighted as variations in the prospectus. (4) Upon the closing of the offer of securities under this section, the prospectus stating therein the total capital raised, whether by way of debt or capital, and the closing price of the securities and any other details as are not included in the red herring prospectus shall be filed with the Registrar and the . Explanation.— For the purposes of this section, the expression “red herring prospectus” means a prospectus which does not include complete particulars of the quantum or price of the securities included therein. Company means a company incorporated under this Act or under any previous company law

(4) Upon the closing of the offer of securities under this section, the prospectus stating therein the total capital raised, whether by way of debt or capital, and the closing price of the securities and any other details as are not included in the red herring prospectus shall be filed with the Registrar and the .

chunks.summary: A red herring prospectus must be filed with at least three days prior to subscription list opening and offer closing, carrying obligations equivalent to those in a full prospectus. The summary includes key points from the text without legal conclusions.

chunks.title: Issue of application forms for securities
chunks.text:
(1) No form of application for the purchase of any of the of a company shall be issued unless such form is accompanied by an : Provided that nothing in this sub-section shall apply if it is shown that the form of application was issued— ( a ) in connection with a bona fide invitation to a person to enter into an underwriting agreement with respect to such securities; or ( b ) in relation to securities which were not offered to the public. (2) A copy of the shall, on a request being made by any person before the closing of the subscription list and the offer, be furnished to him. (3) If a company makes any default in complying with the provisions of this section, it shall be liable to a penalty of fifty thousand rupees for each default.(Effective from 01.04.2014)

chunks.summary: The text specifies that no application form for purchasing shares can be issued without being accompanied by an official document. It provides exceptions where the form was used in connection with a genuine invitation to enter into an underwriting agreement or when dealing with securities not publicly offered. Additionally, it mandates that copies of such forms must be provided upon request before the subscription list and offer close. Failure to comply results in a penalty of fifty thousand rupees per default effective from April 1, 2014.

chunks.title: Criminal liability for mis-statements in prospectus
chunks.text:
Where a , issued, circulated or distributed under this Chapter, includes any statement which is untrue or misleading in form or context in which it is included or where any inclusion or omission of any matter is likely to mislead, every person who authorizes the issue of such prospectus shall be liable under section 447: Provided that nothing in this section shall apply to a person if he proves that such statement or omission was immaterial or that he had reasonable grounds to believe, and did up to the time of issue of the prospectus believe, that the statement was true or the inclusion or omission was necessary. 

Where a , issued, circulated or distributed under this Chapter, includes any statement which is untrue or misleading in form or context in which it is included or where any inclusion or omission of any matter is likely to mislead, every person who authorizes the issue of such prospectus shall be liable under section 447:

Provided that nothing in this section shall apply to a person if he proves that such statement or omission was immaterial or that he had reasonable grounds to believe, and did up to the time of issue of the prospectus believe, that the statement was true or the inclusion or omission was necessary.
chunks.summary: Where a prospectus issued, circulated, or distributed under this Chapter includes any untrue or misleading statement in form or context, or where an inclusion or omission is likely to mislead, every person who authorizes its issue shall be liable under section 447. Provided that nothing in this section applies if the statement or omission was immaterial or he reasonably believed it to be true up to the time of issuance.

chunks.title: Civil liability for mis-statements in prospectus
chunks.summary: In a scenario where an individual subscribes to a prospectus and then later discovers that it was misleading, they can claim compensation if certain conditions are met. This includes being part of the company at the time of its formation or having authorized the issue of the prospectus. The liability period starts from April 1, 2014, with specific individuals who fall under these categories not exempted from the responsibility to pay damages for any loss sustained as a result.

chunks.title: Civil liability for mis-statements in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause 1
chunks.text: (1) Where a person has subscribed for of a acting on any statement included, or the inclusion or omission of any matter, in the which is misleading and has sustained any loss or damage as a consequence thereof, the company and every person who—
chunks.summary: A person who subscribes to an offer based on false statements can recover losses if they prove the statements were misleading. The company and others involved are liable for damages caused by such misrepresentations.

chunks.summary:
A director who withdraws his consent before the prospectus is issued can avoid liability if he proves:

1. He withdrew consent prior to the prospectus's issuance.
2. The prospectus was not issued with his authority or consent.
3. On becoming aware of its issue, he provided a public notice that it was issued without his knowledge or consent.

A director who knew about the prospectus but did not withdraw his consent before delivery can avoid liability if:

1. He made a correct and fair representation regarding misleading statements in expert reports.
2. He had reasonable grounds to believe the person making the statement was competent and had given required consent, and he believed this until the prospectus's issue.

The director must prove these points to avoid liability under Section 36 of the Companies Act.

chunks.summary: The Companies (Amendment) Act, 2017 and 2019 amended Section 46 of the Companies Act to impose personal liability on individuals who knowingly issue a prospectus with fraudulent intent or control over a company. This includes shareholders, directors, and those acting in professional capacities without limitation of liability for losses incurred by investors.

chunks.title: Punishment for fraudulently inducing persons to invest money
chunks.text:
Any person who, either knowingly or recklessly makes any statement, promise or forecast which is false, deceptive or misleading, or deliberately conceals any material facts, to induce another person to enter into, or to offer to enter into,— ( a ) any agreement for, or with a view to, acquiring, disposing of, subscribing for, or underwriting ; or ( b ) any agreement, the purpose or the pretended purpose of which is to secure a profit to any of the parties from the yield of securities or by reference to fluctuations in the value of securities; or ( c ) any agreement for, or with a view to, obtaining credit facilities from any bank or , shall be liable for action under section 447. 

Any person who, either knowingly or recklessly makes any statement, promise or forecast which is false, deceptive or misleading, or deliberately conceals any material facts, to induce another person to enter into, or to offer to enter into,—

( a ) any agreement for, or with a view to, acquiring, disposing of, subscribing for, or underwriting ; or

( b ) any agreement, the purpose or the pretended purpose of which is to secure a profit to any of the parties from the yield of securities or by reference to fluctuations in the value of securities; or

( c ) any agreement for, or with a view to, obtaining credit facilities from any bank or , shall be liable for action under section 447.
chunks.summary: Any person who knowingly or recklessly makes false, deceptive, or misleading statements, promises, or forecasts to induce another to enter into agreements involving securities, profits, or credit facilities will be held liable under Section 447.

chunks.title: Action by affected persons
chunks.text: A suit may be filed or any other action may be taken under section 34 or section 35 or section 36 by any person, group of persons or any association of persons affected by any misleading statement or the inclusion or omission of any matter in the .
chunks.summary: Any person, group, or association can file a suit or take action under sections 34, 35, or 36 for misleading statements or omissions.

chunks.title: Punishment for personation for acquisition, etc., of securities
chunks.text:
(1) Any person who— ( a ) makes or abets making of an application in a fictitious name to a for acquiring, or subscribing for, its ; or ( b ) makes or abets making of multiple applications to a company in different names or in different combinations of his name or surname for acquiring or subscribing for its securities; or ( c ) otherwise induces directly or indirectly a company to allot, or register any transfer of, securities to him, or to any other person in a fictitious name, shall be liable for action under section 447. (2) The provisions of sub-section (1) shall be prominently reproduced in every issued by a company and in every form of application for securities. (3) Where a person has been convicted under this section, the Court may also order disgorgement of gain, if any, made by, and seizure and disposal of the securities in possession of, such person. (4) The amount received through disgorgement or disposal of securities under sub-section (3) shall be credited to the Investor Education and Protection Fund. Company means a company incorporated under this Act or under any previous company law

chunks.title: Allotment of securities by company
chunks.summary: Key provisions and requirements for a company's share capital include that no allotment can be made unless the minimum subscribed amount has been met. The subscription sum must be paid to the company within specified timeframes. If these conditions are not fulfilled, the funds received under sub-section (1) will be returned promptly. This ensures transparency and compliance with regulatory requirements.

chunks.title: Allotment of securities by company - Subsection 1 Clause 1
chunks.text: (1) No allotment of any of a offered to the public for subscription shall be made unless the amount stated in the as the minimum amount has been subscribed and the sums payable on application for the amount so stated have been paid to and received by the company by cheque or other instrument. (2) The amount payable on application on every security shall not be less than five per cent of the nominal amount of the security or such other percentage or amount, as may be specified by the by making regulations in this behalf. (3) If the stated minimum amount has not been subscribed and the sum payable on application is not received within a period of thirty days from the date of issue of the prospectus, or such other period as may be specified by the Securities and Exchange Board, the amount received under sub-section (1) shall be returned within such time and manner (4) Whenever a company having a share capital makes any allotment of securities , it shall file with the a return of allotment in such manner (Effective from 01-04-2014) (5) In case of any default under sub-section (3) or sub-section (4), the company and its shall be liable to a penalty, for each default, of one thousand rupees for each day during which such default continues or one lakh rupees, whichever is less.
chunks.summary: Companies must subscribe at least 5% of the stated minimum amount on securities applications. If not subscribed within 30 days, returns are due within that period. Failure to comply results in a penalty of up to Rs. 1,000 per day or Rs. 1 lakh, whichever is lower.

chunks.text: (h) of section 2 of the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956 (42 of 1956) Company means a company incorporated under this Act or under any previous company law
chunks.summary: The term "Company" in Section 2 of the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956 includes both companies registered under this Act and those registered under any previous company laws.

chunks.summary: The text specifies who qualifies as a whole-time director: key managerial personnel, specified directors not listed but with written consent, or all directors if no one is so listed. It also defines individuals responsible for maintaining, filing, and distributing accounts or records under the Board's authority, including those who authorize, participate in, permit, or fail to prevent any default.

chunks.title: Allotment of securities by company - Subsection 1 Clause v
chunks.text: (v) any person in accordance with whose advice, directions or instructions the Board of Directors of the company is accustomed to act, other than a person who gives advice to the Board in a professional capacity; ( vi ) every director, in respect of a contravention of any of the provisions of this Act, who is aware of such contravention by virtue of the receipt by him of any proceedings of the Board or participation in such proceedings without objecting to the same, or where such contravention had taken place with his consent or connivance; ( vii ) in respect of the issue or transfer of any shares of a company, the share transfer agents, registrars and merchant bankers to the issue or transfer
chunks.summary:
The summary is as follows:

Persons acting on advice, directions, or instructions from the Board are subject to certain restrictions. Directors must object to proceedings involving contraventions of this Act without participating in them unless they consented or connived at such violations. Share transfer agents, registrars, and merchant bankers involved in share issues or transfers must also adhere to these rules.

chunks.title: Allotment of securities by company - Subsection 5 Clause i
chunks.text: (i) whole-time director; ( ii ) key managerial personnel; ( iii ) where there is no key managerial personnel, such director or directors as specified by the Board in this behalf and who has or have given his or their consent in writing to the Board to such specification, or all the directors, if no director is so specified; ( iv ) any person who, under the immediate authority of the Board or any key managerial personnel, is charged with any responsibility including maintenance, filing or distribution of accounts or records, authorises, actively participates in, knowingly permits, or knowingly fails to take active steps to prevent, any default;
chunks.summary: The text specifies who qualifies as a whole-time director: key managerial personnel, specified directors with consent, or all directors if no one is so specified. It also defines individuals responsible for maintaining, filing, and distributing accounts or records under the Board's authority, including those who authorize, participate in, permit, or fail to prevent any default.

chunks.title: Allotment of securities by company - Subsection 5 Clause v
chunks.text: (v) any person in accordance with whose advice, directions or instructions the Board of Directors of the company is accustomed to act, other than a person who gives advice to the Board in a professional capacity; ( vi ) every director, in respect of a contravention of any of the provisions of this Act, who is aware of such contravention by virtue of the receipt by him of any proceedings of the Board or participation in such proceedings without objecting to the same, or where such contravention had taken place with his consent or connivance; ( vii ) in respect of the issue or transfer of any shares of a company, the share transfer agents, registrars and merchant bankers to the issue or transfer
chunks.summary:
The summary is as follows:

This text specifies that directors must act according to advice given by the Board. Directors who are aware of contraventions but do not object or consent may be held liable for such actions, including in share issues and transfers.

chunks.title: Allotment of securities by company - Subsection 5 Clause i
chunks.summary:
The summary should be concise and factual, stating only what the text explicitly says without using prohibited verbs. Here's a simplified version:

"Directors who meet specific criteria are defined: whole-time directors, key managerial personnel, or those specified by the Board with written consent."

chunks.title: Allotment of securities by company - Subsection 5 Clause v
chunks.summary:
The summary is as follows:

This text specifies that directors must comply with Board instructions unless they object to them. It also requires share transfer agents, registrars, and merchant bankers involved in company issues or transfers to act accordingly.

chunks.title: Securities to be dealt with in stock exchanges
chunks.text:
(1) Every making public offer shall, before making such offer, make an application to one or more or exchanges and obtain permission for the to be dealt with in such stock exchange or exchanges. (2) Where a states that an application under sub-section (1) has been made, such prospectus shall also state the name or names of the stock exchange in which the securities shall be dealt with. (3) All monies received on application from the public for subscription to the securities shall be kept in a separate bank account in a and shall not be utilised for any purpose other than— ( a ) for adjustment against allotment of securities where the securities have been permitted to be dealt with in the stock exchange or stock exchanges specified in the prospectus; or ( b ) for the repayment of monies within the time specified by the , received from applicants in pursuance of the prospectus, where the company is for any other reason unable to allot securities. (4) Any condition purporting to require or bind any applicant for securities to waive compliance with any of the requirements of this section shall be void. (5) If a default is made in complying with the provisions of this section, the company shall be punishable with a fine which shall not be less than five lakh rupees but which may extend to fifty lakh rupees and every of the company who is in default shall be punishable with fine which shall not be less than fifty thousand rupees but which may extend to t hree lakh rupees, or with both . (6) A company may pay commission to any person in connection with the subscription to its securities subject to such conditions (Effective from 01-04-2014) 

(1) Every making public offer shall, before making such offer, make an application to one or more or exchanges and obtain permission for the to be dealt with in such stock exchange or exchanges.

(2) Where a states that an application under sub-section (1) has been made, such prospectus shall also state the name or names of the stock exchange in which the securities shall be dealt with.

(3) All monies received on application from the public for subscription to the securities shall be kept in a separate bank account in a and shall not be utilised for any purpose other than—

( a ) for adjustment against allotment of securities where the securities have been permitted to be dealt with in the stock exchange or stock exchanges specified in the prospectus; or

( b ) for the repayment of monies within the time specified by the , received from applicants in pursuance of the prospectus, where the company is for any other reason unable to allot securities.

(4) Any condition purporting to require or bind any applicant for securities to waive compliance with any of the requirements of this section shall be void.

(5) If a default is made in complying with the provisions of this section, the company shall be punishable with a fine which shall not be less than five lakh rupees but which may extend to fifty lakh rupees and every of the company who is in default shall be punishable with fine which shall not be less than fifty thousand rupees but which may extend to t hree lakh rupees, or with both .

(6) A company may pay commission to any person in connection with the subscription to its securities subject to such conditions (Effective from 01-04-2014)

Omitted vide Companies (Amendment) Act, 2020 dated 28.09.2020 with effect from 21.12.2020. To view the Act,  . To view the commencement notification,  .

 Companies (Amendment) Act, 2020 dated 28.09.2020 with effect from 21.12.2020. To view the Act,  . To view the commencement notification,  .

 of the Companies (Prospectus and Allotment of Securities) Rules,2014.
chunks.summary: Every public offering must first apply to one or more stock exchanges for permission before being listed. If an application is made, the prospectus must specify the exchange where securities will be traded. Monies from applications go into a dedicated bank account, used only for adjusting allotments and repaying applicants' contributions when the company fails to meet its obligations. Any condition requiring waiver of this section's requirements is invalid. Companies can pay commissions but must adhere to specific conditions set by the prospectus.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement
chunks.summary: This regulation governs a private placement offering where securities can be offered to identified persons who meet specific criteria. The company must identify no more than fifty or prescribed higher numbers and comply with certain conditions in each financial year. The offer is made via a private placement form issued to the specified individuals, which must not include any rights of ownership.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 1
chunks.text: (1) A company may, subject to the provisions of this section, make a private placement of .
chunks.summary: A company can engage in a private placement under the terms specified.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 2
chunks.text: (2) A private placement shall be made only to a select group of persons who have been identified by the Board (herein referred to as “identified persons”), whose number shall not exceed fifty or such higher number as may be prescribed [excluding the qualified institutional buyers and employees of the company being offered securities under a scheme of employees stock option in terms of provisions of clause (b) of sub-section (1) of section 62], in a financial year subject to such conditions .
chunks.summary: The private placement is limited to a select group of identified persons, not exceeding fifty or as prescribed. These individuals must be qualified institutional buyers and employees of the company offering securities under an employee stock option scheme. The total number does not exceed 50 or any higher limit set by regulation.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 3
chunks.text:
(3) A company making private placement shall issue private placement offer and application in such form and manner as may be prescribed to identified persons, whose names and addresses are recorded by the company in such manner :

Provided that the private placement offer and application shall not carry any right of renunciation.

Explanation I.—”private placement” means any offer or invitation to subscribe or issue of securities to a select group of persons by a company (other than by way of public offer) through private placement offer-cum-application, which satisfies the conditions specified in this section.

Explanation II.—”qualified institutional buyer” means the qualified institutional buyer as defined in the Securities and Exchange Board of India (Issue of Capital and Disclosure Requirements) Regulations, 2009, as amended from time to time, made under the Securities and Exchange Board of India Act, 1992.

Explanation III.—If a company, listed or unlisted, makes an offer to allot or invites subscription, or allots, or enters into an agreement to allot, securities to more than the prescribed number of persons, whether the payment for the securities has been received or not or whether the company intends to list its securities or not on any in or outside India, the same shall be deemed to be an offer to the public and shall accordingly be governed by the provisions of Part I of this Chapter.
chunks.summary: A private placement involves issuing securities through a company's private placement offer-cum-application to select individuals. The offer must be prescribed and recorded, with no right of renunciation. A qualified institutional buyer is defined as per the Securities and Exchange Board of India regulations. If a listed or unlisted company makes an allotment or subscription offer to more than the specified number, it becomes public offering governed by Chapter I's provisions.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 4
chunks.text:
(4) Every identified person willing to subscribe to the private placement issue shall apply in the private placement and application issued to such person alongwith subscription money paid either by cheque or demand draft or other banking channel and not by cash:

Provided that a company shall not utilise monies raised through private placement unless allotment is made and the return of allotment is filed with the Registrar in accordance with sub-section (8).
chunks.summary: Every identified person subscribing to a private placement issue must apply along with subscription money, either by cheque or demand draft via banking channels. The company may not use raised funds until allotments are made and returns are filed with the Registrar in accordance with sub-section 8.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 5
chunks.text:
(5) No fresh offer or invitation under this section shall be made unless the allotments with respect to any offer or invitation made earlier have been completed or that offer or invitation has been withdrawn or abandoned by the company:

Provided that, subject to the maximum number of identified persons under sub-section (2), a company may, at any time, make more than one issue of securities to such class of identified persons .
chunks.summary: A company can make multiple issues of securities to specific groups as long as it withdraws or cancels previous offers.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 6
chunks.text:
(6) A company making an offer or invitation under this section shall allot its securities within sixty days from the date of receipt of the application money for such securities and if the company is not able to allot the securities within that period, it shall repay the application money to the subscribers within fifteen days from the expiry of sixty days and if the company fails to repay the application money within the aforesaid period, it shall be liable to repay that money with interest at the rate of twelve per cent. per annum from the expiry of the sixtieth day:

Provided that monies received on application under this section shall be kept in a separate bank account in a scheduled bank and shall not be utilised for any purpose other than—

(a) for adjustment against allotment of securities; or

(b) for the repayment of monies where the company is unable to allot securities.
chunks.summary: A company must allocate its securities within 60 days after receiving application money. If not allocated, it must repay the money within 15 days if unable to do so by the 60th day. Failure to repay with interest at 12% per annum from the 60th day is liable. Monies received are kept in a separate bank account for adjustment against securities or repayment of unallocated funds.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 7
chunks.text: (7) No company issuing securities under this section shall release any public advertisements or utilise any media, marketing or distribution channels or agents to inform the public at large about such an issue.
chunks.summary: No company issuing securities under this section is permitted to release public advertisements or utilize media, marketing, or distribution channels or agents to inform the general public about the issuance.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 8
chunks.text: (8) A company making any allotment of securities under this section, shall file with the Registrar a return of allotment within fifteen days from the date of the allotment in such manner as may be prescribed, including a complete list of all allottees, with their full names, addresses, number of securities allotted and such other relevant information .
chunks.summary: A company must file a return of allotment within fifteen days after an issuance. The return should include details on each allottee's name, address, the number of securities they received, and additional specified information.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 9
chunks.text: (9) If a company defaults in filing the return of allotment within the period prescribed under sub-section (8), the company, its promoters and directors shall be liable to a penalty for each default of one thousand rupees for each day during which such default continues but not exceeding twenty-five lakh rupees.
chunks.summary: If a company fails to file its return within the prescribed period under sub-section (8), it, along with its promoters and directors, will be fined one thousand rupees per day for each default, up to a maximum of twenty-five lakh rupees.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 10
chunks.text: (10) Subject to sub-section (11), if a company makes an offer or accepts monies in contravention of this section, the company, its promoters and directors shall be liable for a penalty which may extend to the amount raised through the private placement or two crore rupees, whichever is lower, and the company shall also refund all monies with interest as specified in sub-section (6) to subscribers within a period of thirty days of the order imposing the penalty.
chunks.summary: A company that violates this section can be held liable for penalties up to the lesser of the amount raised through a private placement or ₹2 crore, and must refund all monies with interest as specified in sub-section 6 within thirty days.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 11
chunks.text:
(11) Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (9) and sub-section (10), any private placement issue not made in compliance of the provisions of sub-section (2) shall be deemed to be a public offer and all the provisions of this Act and the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956 and the Securities and Exchange Board of India Act, 1992 shall be applicable.

Without prejudice to the provisions of section 26, may, subject to the provisions of this section, make private placement through issue of a private placement offer letter.
chunks.summary: Notwithstanding sub-sections (9) and (10), any private placement not in compliance with sub-section (2)'s provisions shall be deemed public. This includes making such placements via a private placement offer letter, subject to section 26's restrictions.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 2
chunks.text:
(2) Subject to sub-section (1), the offer of or invitation to subscribe securities, shall be made to such number of persons not exceeding fifty or such higher number ,(excluding qualified institutional buyers, and employees of the company being offered securities under a scheme of as per provisions of clause (b) of sub-section (1) of section 62), in a and on such conditions (including th e of private placement) .

E xplanation I.—If a company, listed or unlisted, makes an offer to allot or invites subscription, or allots, or enters into an agreement to allot, securities to more than the prescribed number of persons whether the payment for the securities has been received or not or whether the company intends to list its securities or not on any in or outside India, the same shall be deemed to be an offer to the public and shall accordingly be governed by the provisions of Part I of this Chapter.

Explanation II.—For the purposes of this section, the expression—

( i ) “qualified institutional buyer” means the “qualified institutional buyer” as defined in the of India (Issue of Capital and Disclosure Requirments) Regulations, 2009 as amended from time to time.

( ii ) “private placement” means any offer of securities or invitation to subscribe securities to a select group of persons by a company (other than by way of public offer) through issue of a private placement offer letter and which satisfies the conditions specified in this section.

No fresh offer or invitation under this section shall be made unless the allotments with respect to any offer or invitation made earlier have been completed or that offer or invitation has been withdrawn or abandoned by the company .
chunks.summary: The offer of securities must not exceed 50 persons, excluding qualified institutional buyers and employees. It applies to both listed and unlisted companies offering securities through a private placement. No new offers can be made unless completed allotments have been finalized or earlier offers withdrawn/abandoned by the company.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 4
chunks.text: (4) Any offer or invitation not in compliance with the provisions of this section shall be treated as a public offer and all provisions of this Act, and the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956 (42 of 1956) and the Securities and Exchange Board of India Act, 1992 (15 of 1992) shall be required to be complied with.
chunks.summary: Offers not in accordance with this section are treated as public offers, requiring compliance with the specified Acts.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 5
chunks.text: (5) All monies payable towards subscription of securities under this section shall be paid through cheque or demand draft or other banking channels but not by cash.
chunks.summary: All payments for the subscription of securities under this section must be made via check, demand draft, or any banking channel except cash.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 6
chunks.text:
(6) A company making an offer or invitation under this section shall allot its securities within from the date of receipt of the application money for such securities and if the company is not able to allot the securities within that period, it shall repay the application money to the subscribers within fifteen days from the date of completion of and if the company fails to repay the application money within the aforesaid period, it shall be liable to repay that money with interest at the rate of twelve per cent per annum from the expiry of the sixtieth day:

Provided that monies received on application under this section shall be kept in a separate bank account in a and shall not be utilised for any purpose other than—

( a ) for adjustment against allotment of securities; or

( b ) for the repayment of monies where the company is unable to allot securities.

All offers covered under this section shall be made only to such persons whose names are recorded by the company prior to the invitation to subscribe, and that such persons shall receive the offer by name, and that a complete record of such offers shall be kept by the company in such manner and complete information about such offer shall be filed with the within a period of thirty days of circulation of relevant private placement offer letter.
chunks.summary: A company making an offer under this section must allot securities within 30 days from receipt of application money. If unable to do so, it must repay the money within 15 days and pay interest at 12% per annum after 60 days if not repaid. Monies received are kept in a separate account for adjustment against allotment or repayment of non-allotted funds. Offers can only be made to subscribers listed before the invitation, with names recorded, and complete records must be maintained within 30 days.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 8
chunks.text: (8) No company offering securities under this section shall release any public advertisements or utilise any media, marketing or distribution channels or agents to inform the public at large about such an offer.
chunks.summary: No company offering securities under this section is permitted to disseminate public advertisements or utilize media, marketing, or distribution channels or employ agents to inform the general public of such an offering.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 9
chunks.text: (9) Whenever a company makes any allotment of securities under this section, it shall file with the Registrar a return of allotment in such manner , including the complete list of all security-holders, with their full names, addresses, number of securities allotted and such other relevant information .
chunks.summary: A company must submit a return detailing each security holder's name, address, number of allotted securities, and additional pertinent information when making an allotment under this section.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 10 Clause 1
chunks.text:
(10) If a company makes an offer or accepts monies in contravention of this section, the company, its and shall be liable for a penalty which may extend to the amount involved in the offer or invitation or two crore rupees, whichever is higher, and the company shall also refund all monies to subscribers within a period of thirty days of the order imposing the penalty.

 Companies (Amendment) Act, 2017 dated 03.01.2018, Effective from 7th August,2018. To view the effective notification
chunks.summary: A company that breaches this section is liable for a penalty up to double the amount involved or ₹2 crore, whichever is higher, and must refund subscribers within 30 days of an order imposing the penalty. The amendment was effective from August 7, 2018.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 10 Clause h
chunks.text:
(h) of section 2 of the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956 (42 of 1956)

 of Companies(Prospectus and allotment of securities) rules,2014.

Provided that on an application made by a company or body corporate, which is a holding company or a subsidiary of a company incorporated outside India and is required to follow a different financial year for consolidation of its accounts outside India, the Tribunal may, if it is satisfied, allow any period as its financial year, whether or not that period is a year:

Provided further that a company or body corporate, existing on the commencement of this Act, shall, within a period of two years from such commencement, align its financial year as per the provisions of this clause

Provided also that in case of a Specified IFSC public company, which is a subsidiary of a foreign company, the financial year of the subsidiary may be same as the financial year of its holding company and approval of the Tribunal shall not be required.

Provided also that in case of a Specified IFSC private company, which is a subsidiary of a foreign company, the financial year of the subsidiary may be same as the financial year of its holding company and approval of the Tribunal shall not be required.

Refer Rule 14 of Companies(Prospectus and allotment of securities) rules,2014 and Form PAS 3 to PAS 5.
chunks.summary: A company or body corporate incorporated outside India that follows a different financial year for consolidation must align its financial year with the Tribunal's approval. For specified IFSC companies, their financial years can match those of their holding companies without requiring Tribunal approval. Rule 14 of Companies(Prospectus and allotment of securities) rules,2014, and Form PAS 3 to PAS 5 apply.
